claim: If you were at an Apple store, most of the computers would be running Ubuntu.

supporting.text: Apple stores primarily showcase Apple products, which run macOS, not Ubuntu.

attacks.text: Apple stores primarily showcase Apple products, which run macOS, not Ubuntu.
Some Apple stores may have demo units running Ubuntu to showcase cross-platform compatibility.
Apple's strict control over its retail environment makes it highly unlikely they would display non-Apple operating systems.
Third-party vendors in Apple stores might occasionally use Ubuntu on their demo machines.
Apple's retail agreements typically prohibit third parties from displaying non-Apple operating systems on demo units.

supporting.text: Ubuntu is a Linux distribution, and Apple does not pre-install or promote Linux on its hardware.

attacks.text: Ubuntu is a Linux distribution, and Apple does not pre-install or promote Linux on its hardware.
Some users may install Ubuntu on Apple hardware after purchase, despite Apple's lack of promotion.
The number of users who install Ubuntu on Apple hardware is statistically insignificant compared to those using macOS.
Apple's hardware is designed primarily for macOS, making Ubuntu installations less stable or functional.
Modern Ubuntu distributions have improved compatibility with Apple hardware, reducing stability issues.

supporting.text: Apple's retail strategy focuses on demonstrating macOS and its ecosystem, not third-party operating systems.

attacks.text: Apple's retail strategy focuses on demonstrating macOS and its ecosystem, not third-party operating systems.
Some Apple stores may have demo units running Ubuntu to showcase compatibility with alternative operating systems.
Apple's strict control over hardware and software integration makes it unlikely for them to promote non-macOS systems in stores.
Third-party vendors or special events in Apple stores might temporarily feature Ubuntu on demo machines.
Apple's retail policies strictly prohibit unauthorized OS installations on demo units to maintain brand consistency.

supporting.text: The majority of computers in an Apple store are Macs, which are designed to run macOS exclusively.

attacks.text: The majority of computers in an Apple store are Macs, which are designed to run macOS exclusively.
Some Macs can be modified to run Ubuntu or other Linux distributions, though this is not their default configuration.
Modifying Macs to run Ubuntu is rare and voids warranties, making it unlikely in an Apple store setting.
Apple stores may have demo units running different operating systems for comparison purposes.
Apple's branding and ecosystem focus make it highly improbable they would showcase non-macOS systems prominently.
